content.description: One facet of the study of the origin of life focuses on the nature of the first genetic material. Figure 1 describes a possible scenario, known as the <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> World Hypothesis, that could have led to the evolution of our modern-day genetic material. This hypothesis states that the first genetic material was <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, not <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a transitional period led to the emergence of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as the storage molecule for genetic material.
content.question: Figure 1. A model of the <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> World Hypothesis A scientist wishes to provide experimental evidence to support the model shown in Figure 1 by demonstrating the ability to synthesize an <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule. Which of the following is an alternative hypothesis that can be tested to support the <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> World Hypothesis?

choices.label: A protein template that matches proteins found on the primitive Earth added to a mixture of deoxyribonucleotides will produce double-stranded <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules.

Double strands of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> placed in a harsh environment will unwind and form <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules for long term information storage.

A pool of amino acids can spontaneously form into singleâ€‘stranded <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which would then code for proteins.

A mixture of ribonucleotides such as adenine and uracil will spontaneously form single-stranded chains of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: A mixture of ribonucleotides such as adenine and uracil will spontaneously form single-stranded chains of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
